content:
Downvoted :(

Copied puzzles can still get approved and upvoted by many... do downvote them if you encountered in clash or in Contribution tab... 

https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/5214a3bf421d9ddbb80087a9a812199f596a
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/6225a0bc78303a00236df74219ba707f98f
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/5086d268e874c4909f7edb1c474ca91059f4

All above are dups of the oldest one below
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/566f1b2a3e5f3123e4ac6674b64e491ff61

The cases need to be improved upon. All the test cases showed a letter than is in the original string and that is not true in the validators.  When I played it.  I wrote a whole bunch of extra code to try to show the letter closet to the average that was in the original string. :(

The stub generator implies input string is max 256 chars. Yet, the last test case is much longer.  So the generated input reading skeleton code will result test failure even if player's own code is good - if (s)he does not notice this mistake. This will make this CoC puzzle very annoying.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I'ts cool

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a very good idea and a good level of difficulty.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good Idea, Understandable & good difficulty
Problem statement must be rewritten so that average is well defined. You can guess the meaning from the examples, but that's not desirable.

Yeah, I guess the statement should be smth like "You should return the closest to the average letter of string S. The 'average' letter is the letter with the average ASCII code. In the example, the ASCII codes are as follows: 97, 98, 99, 100, 101. The average is 99 and the closest to it is 'c'".

Edited to fix that.

But anyway, that's a really unoriginal problem and many similar ones already exist...

Also, I did not notice that a few hours ago, but actually this a typical example of a problem where all tests & validators were thought as tests (and some actually corresponding validators should be added).
This is better but make sure to use the term median rather than average when talking about numerical data
